title: Are we afraid of food?
intro: Are food allergies on the increase and if so, why? Do some people believe they have an allergy when they don't? Neil and Alice discuss how the food industry has responded to this growing fear of food and teach some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: What substance is used to treat a severe allergic reaction? Is it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: a condition that makes you feel ill after eating, touching or breathing in a particular substance
our body's defences against infection and disease
a protein found in wheat and some other grains
a disease caused by a lack of Vitamin D in the diet and affects bone development in children
not having enough to eat or enough of the food you need to keep you in good health

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: … and I'm Alice. Neil, what are you eating?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Peanuts.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hmm. Did you know that one of the producers, here, has an allergy to peanuts?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, I didn't – but they're not in the studio with us, so it doesn't matter, does it?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It only takes a tiny piece of peanut to cause a big allergic reaction in some people. An allergy by the way, is a condition that makes you feel ill after eating, touching or breathing in a particular substance.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And food allergies are the subject of today's show.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright, put your peanuts down, Neil and answer today's quiz question. What substance is used to treat a severe allergic reaction? Is it… a) penicillin? b) adrenalin? Or c) aspirin?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, well, I'm going to go for a) penicillin.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out if that's the right answer later on. Now let's listen to Dr Marianne Williams talking about why being too clean may not be a good thing. She is a dietician here in the UK.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Marianne Williams, gastroenterology dietician, UK For roughly the first month of life the immune system is switched off in essence and everything they [babies] get exposed to in that first month in life – dogs, cats, aunts, uncles, grannies, grandpas, family, dirt – everything – that is where they build up all the bacteria that are then going to colonise their gut in the future. Now, if you're born into a very sterile environment, as is increasingly the case in the western world, everything's kept terribly clean, and one of the theories is that we just are not getting enough exposure to a variety of bacteria at that very very early stage in that first month of life.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Dr Marianne Williams. The immune system is our body's defence against infection. And it's switched off – or not working – for the first month of a baby's life.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And through exposure to lots of things in our environment – that's family, pets, dirt and so on – young babies meet different bacteria for the first time which colonise – or live and grow in – their guts.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, but in a sterile environment babies don't get exposed to – or don't meet – a wide enough variety of bacteria. Sterile means completely clean and free of bacteria. And there's a theory that being too clean and bacteria-free – now we have soap, antibiotics and better sanitation – has lead to an increase in allergies.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So dirty play for babies is good – mud, pets, picking stuff up off the floor and eating it.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Did you use to eat food off the floor when you were little, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Used to? I still do. I enjoy food from the floor!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, Neil, what can I say? We're both lucky to be allergy-free. I have a friend who has an allergy to gluten – a protein found in wheat and some other grains – and she has to be very careful about what she eats so she doesn't get ill.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The supermarkets are quite helpful, though, aren't they, with products 'free from this' and 'free from that'?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: This is helpful, yes. But the food industry is now marketing their products to attract consumers who don't have a proven – or tested – allergy.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Why would you buy free-from foods if you don't have a food allergy?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, people have started to believe that certain foods – like gluten or dairy – are bad for us, though there isn't any medical evidence to support this. Let's hear about how rickets – a disease caused by a lack of Vitamin D in the diet – is affecting some children in the UK. This is BBC reporter Mike Williams.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Mike Williams, BBC reporter R ickets is common in the developing world but this is London in the 21st century. These children aren't malnourished because they're too poor to eat well – it's the opposite. Their often middle-class parents are spending money to give them foods with ingredients taken out. It's as if some of us have become unnecessarily frightened of our food.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Rickets usually affects malnourished childrenfrom poor countries– children who don't have enough to eat – and it makes their bones weak. But here in London some parents are buying their children expensive free-from foods – for example to avoid dairy – and are sometimes making them very ill.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It sounds crazy, doesn't it?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah… it's nuts ! Get it? Nuts.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Very good.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. Nuts - that means crazy. Now I think it's time for the answer to today's quiz question.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: OK, then. So earlier in the show I asked: What substance is used to treat a severe allergic reaction? Is it… a) penicillin?  b) adrenalin?  Or c) aspirin?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I said a) penicillin.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And you were wrong, Neil! The correct answer is b) adrenalin. An injection of adrenalin can be used to treat anaphylaxis – or severe allergic reactions – to insect stings, foods, drugs, and other allergens. Antibiotics such as penicillin treat bacterial infections and aspirin is a painkiller you might take for a headache.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, can you tell us the words we heard today again please, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Sure. They are: allergy immune system switched off colonise get exposed to sterile gluten proven rickets malnourished nuts anaphylaxis

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Don't be afraid to join us again soon.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: You know where to find us, don't you? Go to bbclearningenglish.com where you'll find grammar points, vocabulary and more editions of 6 Minute English.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
